response:
Brandon, 

 good question. 

 There is only one version of Lasertron, so the one on the CD is the same as the one online. However, the CD also comes with a demo of Broomsticks 3D which is not anywhere else. However, to run Broomsticks 3D, you will need a capable 3D graphics card that has OpenGL support.

name: (nameless)
comments: i think your price is to high,sure games out there are like $30-$40, but those games have lots of memory, they are in 3d, and youll probably be playing them longer than broomsticks, and your game is 2d, doesnt use a lot of memory or programming, compared to the games out there, yours is 1/3-1/4 the price! i say at the most sell it for $5,because ive seen 3d games that are $10 and are way more sophisticated than yours,its a good game, but the price is high, thats way half the people that write in this guestbook cant.
response:
If you think that the value of a program is based on the amount of memory it uses, then you've been using too many Microsoft products! Hahahahaaha! :-) 

 No seriously, the full version is a lot of fun and there are many ways to play that will keep you interested. I just got two emails today from people that bought it that said it was the best game that they bought in some time. 

 3D games are not necessarily better. I've played a bunch of 3D games that get boring quick. However, if you insist on 3D, don't forget that there is also the Broomsticks 3D game on the CD: 

 [Broomsticks 3D screenshots](br3d.html) 

 It is a Quake3-style renderer, meaning that it is on the opposite end of the spectrum (from the 2D game) in terms of rendering technology. You will need a decent 3D graphics card just to run it.

name: (nameless)
comments: your game is basic, a little complex, but still pretty insignificant compared to other games your price! im trying to make a point that your game is $10, ive seen games for the same price, and they are in 3d,and 20x more complex! im just saying people could buy other games that are better than yours for the same price! and those screen shots are fake, theres no broomsticks 3-d. thats just some other game your developing at cave.
response:
Are complex games necessarily better? Think about it for a while. 

 The truth is that what makes a game good is gameplay. Quality of graphics is also important, but secondary. Why did Tetris sell so well? 

 There is a Broomsticks 3D. I'm using some of the same code that I used for one of my CAVE projects, but it is a separate game that runs on regular computers. I have the ability to do really high end 3D graphics (that's my job), but the truth is that most people will probably enjoy the regular Broomsticks more than the 3D one. The 3D one is more complicated and harder to play.

name: (nameless)
comments: let me ask you one question.do you beleive games should be priced by how good they are?
response:
No, not necessarily. People will just buy more copies of good games. Games are priced by many factors. Mostly, the cost of developing the game and the cost of distributing it. 

 In my case, development costs were low (just my time), but distribution is not cheap because I make the CDs myself in small quantities. 

 Really, in the end I chose the price because I thought it was reasonable. Anybody who really wants my game should be able to save up $10.

name: Peter Cardi
comments: Broomsticks is so cool! The only problem is the controls aren't very responsive, and there's no "down" button. An idea for a future game: two red balls and two black balls, where one of the red balls is invisible until you fly into it.
response:
Peter, 

 actually, that is on purpose. To make it feel like you are flying, I don't allow you to turn on a dime. You have to overcome your momentum in one direction to start going the other way. The best way to play the game is to click on the buttons fast (rather than holding them down). 

 I'm considering a down button but I'll have to make sure it helps the gameplay.

name: Matthew Davis
comments:
All I can say is : Wow!

 Ok, I can say a bit more than that =Þ Great demo. I love the new passing feature and the clouds in front ^-^ Nice touch. I see that it should support BR1 character and item sets providing that the user converts the GIF file to BMP, so that's also great.
 I think that it would be nice to be able to change the poles when making a custom item set, or... Ok, steering clear of the animation thing =Þ 

 Well, all in all, it's a great demo, even if it's an early one, and I can't wait to see it in the weeks (or months) to come. 

 -Matt
response:
Thanks Matt! I will think of a way to allow the poles to be modified. 

 Update: - if you download the newest version (0.3), you can make a custom pole by creating a 20x185 BMP and naming it pole1.bmp. The hoop is still in the items file though... 

 Also, I will come up with a way to allow more animations and yet be compatible with old character sets.

name: Matthew Davis
comments:
Actually, I understood all that ^-^

 Well cool, so, like, with the BR2 characters, you could have as many frames as the creator desires for each player then? 
 Cool. So, this means that Broomsticks will, at last, have increased animation, right? Sure, five characters within each set, but that's absolutely fine! Don't need any more than that!

 Now, the animation, would it just be, for example, the cape flapping around while flying or something (no in-between actions), or actual in-depth animation, so like, still for example, the cape flapping around, but actions inbetween going up and down or left and right too?

 Either way, it'll mean more work for the character creator too, but what the hey! It'll definately put a lot more edge in character set competitions!!

 (\(^o^)/) Yayay!!!!!!!!!! 

 -Matt
response:
Right, there are no "inbetween actions" in the game. However, with multiple frames for each of the 4 states (up-left, up-right, down-left, down-right), there will be plenty to do! 

 I'm glad you are excited. I look forward to seeing what you can make with the new capabilities!

name: Matthew Davis
comments:
Ok, I just downloaded the new demo and went straight to the player graphics for answers. Cape flapping around w/o animations inbetween.

 That's cool though. Having animations inbetween actions would have been really confusing now that I think more about it ^-^

 But cool. Yes, I'm gonna have tons of fun making more sets now!

 *evil grin* Nyeheheheheheheheheeeeeeeeeeeeeee!! 

 -Matt

name: Matthew Davis
comments:
Wow, it's so quiet in here. 

 I blame the American School Holidays Placement Department--er--Thingy! =Þ
 Now, being from Australia, I expect that the arrangement of school holidays are different to that of America.
 I don't know, but I think mum said that, like, it's school non-stop for 9 months, followed by a 3 month summer holiday break, right? Well, it's different for us Aussies.
 Holidays follow a pattern of approx. 10 weeks of school, then 1 week of easter holidays, approx. 10 weeks of school, then 2 weeks of end-of-semester holidays, approx. 10 weeks of school, then 2 weeks of September holidays (yay!), then approx. 10 weeks of school, followed by 6 weeks of Christmas Holidays! Whee!!

 Methinks American kids and college/university students should get a more scattered holiday routine =D

 What? Oh right! This is a broomsticks guestbook!! lol, oh well. That happens some times ;)
 -Matt
response: Actually, so-called "year around schooling" is starting to happen at some grade schools around here (6-12 years old).

name: Daniel
comments: Hey Paul, i have not got to try broomsticks 3d yet except for the demo. And our computer is so old the download doesn't realy work so i'm hoping i'm one of the winners of the backgrounds contest so i can try the full version. Anyway i was going to ask if there are quaffles(red) in the game or just the snitch and black bludgerers? Also please keep it so you can still play a quidditch GAME. Not just find things in the castle. Finding the brooms does sound awesome though, do they make you go faster???
response:
Daniel, 

 I'm sorry to say, but if the demo version does not work on your computer then the Full Version will not work either. Most of the time you can get it to work by getting the newest OpenGL drivers for your graphics card. However, if your computer is older then it may not even have a 3D graphics card or it may have one that does not support OpenGL. 

 Yes, you can play a GAME and all of the balls are there. However, there is no opponent yet, so it is practice for what will come later. :-) 

 Yes, each broomstick has a different max speed and acceleration. This means each broom has a certain speed and agility. For instance, in the Full Version there is one that is very fast but hard to control. :-) In both versions, there is one broom that is hard to find but is very fast and agile.

name: Matthew Davis
comments: Um... About the graphics card... See, I used it from a school computer, and I don't think it has a graphics card. I'm not too sure about it. I'm sure it's a great game, but I simply can't play it because it refuses to operate. It says it performed an illigal operation and closed. If anyone else knows their computer colours (and if you experience the same gamma colour) you'll notice that it 'ups' the colour brightness by 128, but it doesn't affect the three primary colours; that's probably because only one colour is set to 255 and the remaining two are set at 'Numero Zero'. Long story short: I don't know what the graphics card is, but 'M' might! (PS: I'd be very suprised if this message gets a big response message from you. From 'M', not too suprised)

name: Here's a cool Quidditch game!
comments: QUIDDITCH This game of Quidditch is played on a field 7 boxes long, 3 wide, and 3 high. The Goal-Posts are at either end of the stadium, at ground level, middle square (you can only shoot if youre in this square). The best way to represent this is by making three flat fields, and laying them side by side to show the three levels. BEFORE EACH PLAYER PLAYS Each Bludger moves one square closer to the nearest Seeker. The Quaffle stays still. Then, see whose side the Quaffle is in. This person plays first (if the Quaffle is in the middle, flip a coin.) Then the other player plays. Repeat the process until the Snitch is caught. ON YOUR TURN You may: 1. Move your pieces. 2. Play cards. 3. Replenish your hand to 7 cards. MOVING YOUR PIECES Each Chaser and Beater may move one space in any direction. Chasers may move two, and they may change direction in mid-move. The Keeper must stay in the Goal-Box. If the Quaffle is NOT in anyones possession, and is in the same space as one of your Chasers, it is taken by your Chaser and is now in your possession. Other players cant touch the Quaffle. If the Bludger is in the same space as a Beater, it is hit two spaces in any direction. If any other player is in the same space as a Bludger, they must drop the Quaffle if they have it and get knocked one space in the same direction the Bludger hit them (of course they cant leave the field). PLAYING A CARD Cards are really important. Without cards you cant pass, steal, or shoot! Here are the cards: DIVE A movement boost card. Any Chaser or Beater may move straight down one extra space (Seekers two!). SPRINT A movement boost card. Any Chaser or Beater may move one extra space in any horizontal direction (no diagonals, sorry!)(Seekers two!) ROCKET A movement boost card. Any Chaser or Beater may move straight up one space (Seekers two!) PASS A passing card. You may transfer the Quaffle to any other Chaser one space in any horizontal direction and two spaces in any downward direction (diagonals are OK!)(no upward passes, sorry!) GREAT PASS A passing card. You may transfer the Quaffle to any other Chaser one space in any upwards direction, two spaces in any horizontal direction and three spaces in any downward direction (diagonals are OK!) STEAL You may take possession of the Quaffle if one of your Chasers is in the same box as an opposing Chaser carrying the Quaffle, or you may take possession of the Quaffle if one of your Chasers is in the same box as a Chaser who is receiving a pass, or you may take possession of the Quaffle if one of your Chasers is in any box through which the Quaffle is being passed. This card may be played at any time! SHOOT This card may be played at any time when one of your Chasers, carrying the Quaffle, is in the Goal-Box. Simply pick a number between one and three. Your opponent does the same. If you picked different numbers, you score ten Points and the Quaffle reappears in the center of the pitch (level 2, width 3, length 5)! If you picked the same number, the Keeper blocks the Quaffle and it becomes the possession of the first enemy Chaser to fly into that half of the field. SNITCH When you get this card, the Snitch appears. Dont tell your opponent you have this card! The card will give a set of coordinates in this order: height, length, width. The first Seeker to enter this square earns 150 points for his team, and the game ends. There is only ONE Snitch card! IF your opponent ever stumbles into a square which borders the Snitch square, you MUST show him/her your Snitch card. If they stumble into the Snitch square itself, of course they catch the Snitch! To make the Snitch random, make ten Snitch cards before each game and hide one in the deck. Whoever has the highest score when the Snitch is caught wins!
response:
Wow, that's a long post! :-) 

 The game sounds interesting but the rules are a bit complicated. :-) Where did you learn about it?

name: Kalle Kalmari
comments: Hi paul i got Ati rage mobility-p agp (english) (for laptop) graphics card i think i can get update from www.ati.com i have windows 2000 professional and in glsetup isn't opengl for windows 2000!
response:
For laptops, you may want to check the laptop manufacturer's website. For instance, I have an IBM Thinkpad X20 with an ATI Rage Mobility-M and I found the new drivers on IBM's Thinkpad site, not at ATI. 

 Let me know what kind of performance you get. It runs pretty slowly on my laptop. However, on my desktop (which has an Nvidia GeForce2 Ultra), it runs extremely fast! Really, you need about 15 fps (frames per second) for it to be playable. The more fps you have, the smoother the animation. However, if you get above 60 fps, it doesn't really matter anymore because your eyes can't tell the difference. On my desktop it runs at well over 60, even at high resolutions like 1280x1024!

name: Ted Kendrick
comments: How do you make Br3d skins? Can they be skins for other games, too?
response:
Ted, 

 all you need to do is find repeating textures (images that repeat like wallpaper). There are many out there. Here's a good website: 

 [http://www.grsites.com/textures/](http://www.grsites.com/textures/) 

 I found this site by doing a google search with this: 

 free + tiling + texture 

 Then, once you have found your nice images, scale them to 256x256 with your favorite paint program. Then save them as .jpg and put them into the skin zip file. You need to have the same paths and filenames as the original images in the zip file. Probably the easiest way to do this is to extract the zip archive, replace the images, and then zip it up again. 

 Yes, most games do use repeating textures. However, I want to avoid using textures from copyrighted games. So, please find textures that are free to use.

name: daniel
comments: how do you get the people to fly in your game broomsticks?
response: The program redraws the field over and over very quickly. Each time the field is redrawn, the positions of the players are updated. The positions are calculated with some simple physics. If you hit the up key you get some upward velocity. If you don't touch anything then you begin to accelerate downward (gravity). Since you are flying, the players start to float down rather than drop like rocks. :-)

name: Dillo
comments: You said before that you made this game for fun, not profit. If that is true, why don't you give the full version away for free. I'm sure we would all be happy to get it in our email.
response:
Good question. I enjoy making games and I want as many people as possible to play them. That's why I host them on my web server and allow people to play them online for free. 

 With Broomsticks, at first I only had one version (what is now the demo version). I could have kept it that way. However, I decided to try something new. I made a full version that has a bunch of extra features, sounds, and documentation. There are two reasons why I sell the full version: 

 1) I run my own web server and serve up a bunch of things. I have to keep my online games very small so that I don't swamp my server. All of the extra features, utilities, and documentation make the full version 30 times bigger than the demo version. The last two months I have had over 100,000 downloads of my demo version (your browser downloads it before you play). If everybody could download my full version that would be too much bandwith. 

 2) The full version took me a good amount of time to make and so I think it is worth something. People who have the full version agree with me. :-) I'm not making lots of money off of this, but it is nice to get something. :-)

response: It depends on what graphics card you have. Right click on the desktop and click on Properties. This will take you to the "Display Properties" dialog. Click on the Settings tab. The driver documentation will tell you if the driver supports OpenGL. Most cards do support both DirectX and OpenGL but some cards only support DirectX.

response:
Thanks for helping out with the guestbook. Given how busy I am, I think that a message board format would be better. Specifically, it would be good to have a multiple subject message board. Ideas for topics would be: 

 - general discussion
 - technical problems
 - contributions (characters, skins, etc)
 

 This way, people could post new content (skins, characters, etc) without going through me. Of course, moderators would be needed.

I am very impressed by the addictive simplicity of your outstanding game. It is a program that can provide hours of fun without the need for fast computers and long periods of load time. In short, your game is awesome! Keep up the excellent work! Lee
response: Thanks Lee! Guestbook entries like this have made this all worthwhile.

name: Quidditch Fan
comments: Yo Paul, I really liked the way you executed this Quidditch game. Most other programmers use a top-down perspective (like the Mystery Monkey people). Your idea was extremely cool. Minor quibble: I played a few games against my sister and figured out right away that the easiest way to win is just to stay on top of your opponent and squish them whenever they try to fly. You have complete control of the field - I even beat the best computer mode that way. Maybe instead of starting over on the ground players could just get "bounced"? Probably this strategy doesn't work with more than two players.... Wouldn't it be really cool to have a 3D Quidditch game (first-person view, leaning ver your broom i guess) where your mouse pointer directed which way to go? That would combine the best aspects of the top-down view (turns, dodges) with your perspective (dives, climbs). Now THAT would be cool. Signing off, Noodles (no, it's not my real name :-)
response:
Thanks! 

 True, however, when you add the black balls into the mix it isn't always easy to stay above the other player constantly. It is especially hard if the field is smaller or there are more than 2 black balls. You can control these parameters in the full version. 

 Actually, I am working on a 3D game. An early version of it comes with the CD. And yes, it is very cool! :-) You use the mouse just like you mentioned!

Lukas, 

 good question. The engine is portable (OpenGL and SDL). However, I have no experience compiling on Macs. So, my answer is that once I finish the game I will find out how to compile it for Mac users. So yes, it will also be for macs unless I run into unforseen problems. 

 Right now I'm not sure how long it will take. I will let you know though. 

 I'm planning on including it on the same CD (with Broomsticks), just like I am doing now with the early Windows version. I will also provide a way for people to upgrade if they have an older version.

comments: Katie, it costs heaps to make games for PSX or N64. However, I know where to buy a program that lets you make your own PSX games. If you want to know more about it either reply to this or send me the full version of this game. LOL But you can always hack a PSX CD and then test it with Bleem! (Bleem! cost $30 and i will send it to you for free for your broomsticks full version) LOL Also, it's a pretty good game i just wish i was allowed to send $10 dollars :(
response:
Brad is right. Consoles are generally "closed" platforms. This means that you are supposed to use expensive development tools that come from the console manufacturer. Of course, there are people who hack and reverse engineer consoles. I've found a bunch of stuff but I don't really have the time to get into this sort of thing. 

 However, Sega Dreamcast announced that they will have a web browser that supports Java. This means that you will be able to play the online version of Broomsticks on a Dreamcast. I'll have to look into this... 

 Still, Brad, I'm interested in the program that you mentioned. 

 I normally do really high end 3D graphics for million dollar Virtual Reality Systems. You can read more on my [homepage](../). That stuff is amazing! However, very few people have access to such equipment.

name: Daniel
comments:
"Paul, problem... again... but it's about skins. How do I change it? The skins11.zip can't change back into a "File"... If this makes no sense, just recommend anything..."

 To edit a skin you first have to unzip all the files in the .zip. Then use any photoediting software to make your changes to the skin. When your done, zip all those files back together and make sure that .zip file isn't named the same thing as any other Broomstick 3D file. To use this skin while playing the game you have to make sure that it has the ".zip" at the end of its file name and that all other skin files do not. To remove the ".zip" from a file name just rename the file. Then when you run the game your new skin should be applied.

Hope that covers anything. I haven't made a skin in a long time so if I missed something sorry.

name: Nick "Knuckles" Spadina
comments: Dear Paul, I think that your game rocks. Would it be possible to make something that would enable all of Broomsticks loyal fans to challenge each other? Maybe make teams? Also, what program did you use to make Broomsticks and what internet adress would I be able to get one? I'd like to make my own computer games, although I'm only 14. Keep up the good work Paul! - Nick
response:
Thanks Nick! 

 I'm a programmer and so I made Broomsticks from scratch using the Java programming language. Programming can take years to master, but it is well worth it. I started when I was in grade school! 

 As for your suggestion, that would be cool. If I have time I should try doing something like that. I have done networking before. The only problem with doing networking for Broomsticks is that Java only trusts the host for security reasons. This means that all network traffic for the game would have to go through my computer, which would probably be too much given the number of people that are playing Broomsticks! Still, I will consider it.

name: Steven z
comments: How do you make skins
response:
Good question. I need to make a tutorial. For now, here are the basic steps: 

 1) Unzip a skin pack (using Winzip or pkunzip) 2) go into directories that were unzipped 3) edit images (textures) using your favorite paint program 4) run the game (it will pick up new skins from the directories) 5) when you are done, zip the directories back up into a zip file and send it to me.

name: Nika
comments: WOW! Your Broomsticks Experts Demo is super! The first time I gave it a shot I actually lost the game-but only by ten. I should know, I've probably been to every web page that has the slightest mention of Harry Potter, Quidditch, Hogwarts or magic! I'm even enrolled to many virtual Hogwarts schools, and for some I'm on the Ravenclaw Quidditch team! But this is the best of all games, and I think that with your talent and clever ideas, it will be for quite some time!
response:
Thanks Nika! For even more challenge, make sure you hit f to make the computer player even harder! 

 However, the Full Version is much much better than the Experts Demo. In the next few days, I'm going to put up a demo version that will hopefully give people a better idea of what the Full Version is like.

name: James
comments: How much memory (MB) does the broomsticks game take up? Do you have to have any other special program like flash 5 to be able to run the game?
response:
Wow James you have a lot of questions. :-) 

 You can play the game right off the CD. If you install it, it takes up only a few MB on your hard-drive. It doesn't use much system memory at all. You do not need any special program to run the game. All you need is a web browser. If you can play the demo version in your browser, you will be able to play the full version.

comments: Which is better the cd or the floppy?
response:
They both have the Full Version on them. However, the CD also has a demo of the 3D version (it does not fit on the floppy). Also, the CD is cooler looking. :-) 

 Really, the only reason for getting the floppy is if you only have a slot-loading CD-ROM (no tray).

name: KIWOOK
comments: Commenting: The reason why I dont feel like buy your game is because A chimp I know at the zoo well he says PC games are much better than games such as Video game systems. But he says that The : XBox , a video game in most cases is better than a computer is that true? I still like your game!
response:
huh? 

 There are advantages to both PCs and consoles. The advantage of the console is that it is much cheaper and that the games are guaranteed to work. The advantage of the PC is that you can get newer hardware as it comes out (a console's hardware doesn't change). PCs also run at higher resolution. 

 The new consoles coming out (like the Xbox) will be interesting because initially their performance will be as good if not better than a high end PC.

name: Jeremy
comments: I have some more things that you might like that I forgot to post: 1) You might want to consider buying Install Maker (Pro). It's a REALLY cool install program maker. I just think FreeExtractor's just not enough (I downloaded it, 'cause I noticed you used it for BR3D.) You can get it from "www.clickteam.com" If you get the PRO version (99$ US), you can create seperate versions of the program (Install Broomsticks & Broomsticks 3D in the same installer!) and it's really easy to use. Just, if you DO buy it, and you get PRO, just make sure any "Mutually Exclusive" check boxes are clear. The NORMAL version ($29 US I think) is pretty cool too. What's really cool, is that if you're building your installer onto a floppy, if it takes more than the capacity of the disk, it spans the installer across the disk. When you install Install Maker, it only takes up 1-2MB of disk space! And the installers it creates (you create!), the actual wizard, is only 60KB and the files in it is compressed EQUAL to the compression of WinZip!!! I highly recommend it, and the installer to install Install Maker is an example of an installer made with Install Maker PRO, and you can also try unregistered versions of it (no evaluation) which just have an ad screen at the end. 2) I think it's VERY rude to post rude comments on guestbooks. Anyone does is VERY rude. Paul Rajlich went to all the LOTS OF EFFORT of making these games and people say stuff like "MONKEY ? IS WAY BETTER THAN BROOMSTICKS"! Of course that <- is completely the opposite. I think you maybe should create a submitting script that scans the comments for stuff like that and removes those entries. 3) You've got a good brain, Paul. 4) You might also want to get The Games Factory or Jamagic to make Broomsticks, also from clickteam.com Cheers, Jeremy
response:
Thanks for the info Jeremy. 

 As for the negative comments, I don't mind. The only comments that I remove are ones that are clearly offensive (bad language). Besides, most of the posts are very positive. Thanks everybody! 

 The game makers look interesting. However, a programmer like myself will always want to program. :-) Even the most powerful game makers will not give you the control that programming will...

response:

 There are some technical problems with making this work well through a Java applet (in a browser), so don't expect too much. :-) One solution would be to make a standalone application for the game, but I may not get to that...

name: Larrin
comments: You don't have a default e-mail program set for your computer. What happens when you click the e-mail this person button is it takes the address and sends it to your default e-mail program. You can still e-mail them with out it though. Right click on the link to e-mail them, then click copy shortcut. You can go to your Yahoo or Hotmail or what and paste it (right click in the place where the address goes and click paste, or just push ctrl+v) and then you can delete the mailto: part at the beginning. Also when you hover the mouse over the link to the address you can see in the bottom left what it's going to, in this case it would say mailto:cubee2006@yahoo.com for me.

response: A 3D accelerator is a graphics card that is able to improve the speed of 3D applications by implementing certain functions in the hardware. You may have one already and may just need to get the right drivers for it.

Matthew,

The reasoning behind the new white block textures is that they are very bright and have a lot of contrast.  (\(^o^)/) - This is a happy expression. It's not mine, someone else made that one... Can't remember who... =D

 ?? °.° ?? - That's my really confused expression. I rarely use that one.

name: Daniel
comments:
Paul,
 I think that on the Full Version you should add the option of controling the Gold Ball's speed. You could have a 'Slow', 'Medium', and 'Fast' (Default of current speed) speed.
 I think having the option to control the gold ball's speed would add more fun to the game (if that's possible ;-) ) and I would probably use the gold ball more often.
response:
Thanks for the suggestion. I would have to try it out and see what happens. Wouldn't it be too easy to catch then? 

 Really, the problem with the gold ball in the 2D game is that there is not much room for it to go. I think that it works better in the 3D game...
